list.title: Question 1
list.content: What is adisadvantageto an organism of being multicellular rather than unicellular?A.\hspace{1em}Larger body sizeB.\hspace{1em}Ability to adapt to their surroundingsC.\hspace{1em}The need for a complex exchange systemD.\hspace{1em}Cell differentiation
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Multicellular organisms are comprised of numerous specialised cells, enabling them to achieve larger sizes compared to unicellular organisms. This results in them needing exchange systems, such as the circulatory and respiratory systems, to manage waste removal and to acquire essential substances such as oxygen and nutrients. In contrast, unicellular organisms can rely on simple diffusion.Choice Cis correct.Choice Ais incorrect because although multicellular organisms often have a larger body size than unicellular organisms, this can be advantageous to them.Choice Bis incorrect, as multicellular organisms adapting to their environment more easily is an advantage.Choice Dis incorrect, as cell differentiation, where cells become specialised for specific functions, is an advantage as it allows for the division of labour amongst cells.

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Which statement about eukaryotic cells is correct?A.\hspace{1em}Eukaryotic chromosomes are circular and the DNA is associated with histone proteinsB.\hspace{1em}Eukaryotic cells have looped DNA molecules which are not associated with proteins in the nucleusC.\hspace{1em}Eukaryotic cells have linear DNA molecules associated with proteinsD.\hspace{1em}Eukaryotic cells have linear DNA molecules that are not associated with histone proteins
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The chromosomes of eukaryotes are linear, and the DNA is coiled around histone proteins (Choice C).Choice Ais incorrect because eukaryotic DNA molecules are not circular.Choice Bis incorrect because eukaryotic cells do not have looped DNA in the nucleus.Choice Dis incorrect because the linear DNA molecules in eukaryotic cells are coiled around histone proteins.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
What type of cell is shown in the image?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb7991c0-6eee-4fa1-81bc-74345942fcf6/images/be97c032-ac41-4e78-8ebb-0e74c97826e6/BI0392ii.png)

[Source: Adapted from Itayba, Hebrew Wikipedia. (2016, March 1).Category: Electron Microscope Images. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved May 19, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_microscopy.jpg  Copyright under CC BY 3.0]A.\hspace{1em}A eukaryotic cell because it contains mitochondriaB.\hspace{1em}A prokaryotic cell because it has a plasma membraneC.\hspace{1em}A eukaryotic cell because it does not have a nucleusD.\hspace{1em}A prokaryotic cell because it contains ribosomes
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Eukaryotic cells contain mitochondria but prokaryotic cells do not.Choice Ais correct.Choices BandDare incorrect as the cell is not prokaryotic; it has a nucleus.Choice Cis incorrect because the cell has a nucleus.

list.title: Question 4
list.content: Which statement(s) about the endosymbiotic theory is/are true?I.\hspace{1em}It provides evidence for the origin of prokaryotes.II.\hspace{.7em}It provides evidence for the origin of eukaryotes.III.\hspace{.5em}It provides evidence for spontaneous generation.A.\hspace{1em}II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The endosymbiotic theory states that larger prokaryotes engulfed smaller prokaryotes, which were the ancestors of modern chloroplasts and mitochondria, eventually evolving into eukaryotes.Choice Ais correct.Statement I (Choices BandD) is incorrect as prokaryotes were not formed by the endosymbiotic theory. Statement III (Choice C) is incorrect as spontaneous generation is impossible.

list.title: Question 5
list.content: Which structure in a eukaryotic cell would also be present in a prokaryotic cell?A.\hspace{1em}NucleusB.\hspace{1em}Plasma membraneC.\hspace{1em}80S ribosomesD.\hspace{1em}Histones
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Both eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells contain a plasma membrane;Choice Bis correct.Choices A, CandDare incorrect as they are present in eukaryotic cells but not prokaryotic cells.

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Which row in the table correctly identifies structures which are present (✓) or absent (✕)  in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells?StructureProkaryotic cellsEukaryotic cellsA.\hspace{1em}70S Ribosomes in Cytosol✓✕B.\hspace{1em}Cell Wall✕✓C.\hspace{1em}Mitochondria✓✕D.\hspace{1em}Naked DNA✕✓
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Prokaryotic cells contain 70S ribosomes in their cytoplasm, while eukaryotic cells have 80s cytoplasmic ribosomes, soChoice Ais correct.Choice Bis incorrect as prokaryotes have a cell wall, but not all eukaryotes do.Choice Cis incorrect as prokaryotes do not contain membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria, but eukaryotes do. *Choice Dis incorrect, as prokaryotic cells have naked DNA, whereas eukaryotic cells contain DNA within a nuclear membrane.

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
These photographs show the same section of a human retina. What is the reason for the difference between the two diagrams?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/34eb27e0-6237-4360-ac56-27073683e781/images/58faa56f-a89c-49e0-824a-bfbe19119bb9/BI0391_1.2.png)

[Source: Nestl, A. (2012, January 17).FileAMD Super resolution Cremer.png - Wikimedia Commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 16, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Opthalmology_AMD_Super_Resolution_Cremer.png Copyright under CC BY 3.0]A.\hspace{1em}The photograph on the right was taken using an electron microscope.B.\hspace{1em}The photograph on the right is at a higher resolution.C.\hspace{1em}The photograph on the right is at a higher magnification.D.\hspace{1em}The photograph on the right shows the ultrastructure of the cells.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The resolution is the ability to distinguish between two objects.Choice Bis correct.Choices AandDare incorrect because a photograph taken using an electron microscope would allow the ultrastructure of the cells (fine detail of cells, such as organelles) to be observed.Choice Cis incorrect because these photographs are magnified at the same power.

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Which of the following correctly describes the images produced by electron microscopes?I.High resolutionII.High magnificationIII.ColouredA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Electron micrographs have high resolution (Statement I) and high magnification (Statement II)Choice Bis therefore correct.Electron micrographs are not coloured (Statement III).Choice Ais incorrect as it only includes one correct statement.Choices CandDare incorrect because they includeStatement III.

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Parameciumproduces enzymes that catalyse different chemical reactions taking place in the cytoplasm. What function of life is demonstrated in this situation?A.\hspace{1em}ExcretionB.\hspace{1em}HomeostasisC.\hspace{1em}ReproductionD.\hspace{1em}Metabolism
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice A- Excretion is the removal of metabolic wastes from the organism. Paramecia expel waste products such as carbon dioxide through the process of diffusion.Choice B- Homeostasis pertains to the ability of living things to maintain a stable internal environment. Paramecia maintain a stable internal condition by expelling excess water using the contractile vacuole.Choice C-   Reproduction is the biological process by which organisms produce offspring that are biologically similar to themselves. Paramecia can reproduce sexually through meiosis and asexually through mitosis.Choice D- Metabolism refers to all the chemical reactions in organisms such as anabolic and catabolic reactions. Paramecia produce enzymes that catalyse different catabolic and anabolic reactions in the cell.

list.title: Question 10
list.content: Which organelle has a double membrane?A.\hspace{1em}Rough endoplasmic reticulumB.\hspace{1em}Golgi apparatusC.\hspace{1em}NucleusD.\hspace{1em}Vacuole
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The nucleus is the only organelle among the options listed that has a double membrane. The nuclear envelope consists of two lipid bilayers: the inner membrane and the outer membrane.Choice Cis correct.Choices A,BandDare incorrect as they all have a single membrane.

list.title: Question 11
list.content: Which row in the table correctly identifies structures which are present (✓\checkmark✓) or absent (×\times×)  in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells?StructureProkaryotic cellsEukaryotic cells\hspace{1em}A.\hspace{1em}80S ribosomes✓\checkmark✓×\times×\hspace{1em}B.\hspace{1em}Plasma membrane×\times×✓\checkmark✓\hspace{1em}C.\hspace{1em}Nucleus✓\checkmark✓×\times×\hspace{1em}D.\hspace{1em}Mitochondria×\times×✓\checkmark✓
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Prokaryotic cells do not contain mitochondria but eukaryotic cells do.Choice Dis correct.Choice Ais incorrect as eukaryotes (as well asArchae) contain 80S ribosomes.Choice Bis incorrect as both eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells contain a plasma membrane.Choice Cis incorrect as eukaryotic cells contain a nucleus but prokaryotic cells do not.

list.title: Question 12
list.content: Which structure found in a eukaryote has a double membrane?A.\hspace{1em}Golgi apparatusB.\hspace{1em}MitochondrionC.\hspace{1em}LysosomeD.\hspace{1em}Endoplasmic reticulum
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Organelles of a eukaryotic cell are enclosed by a single or double membrane. Double membrane-bound organelles include the nucleus, mitochondria, and chloroplasts. So, a mitochondrion has a double membrane.The Golgi apparatus (Choice A), lysosome (Choice C), and endoplasmic reticulum (Choice D) all have a single membrane.

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
The photomicrograph showsChlorella, the cells of which contain chlorophyll.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a549579f-5d03-4a34-99a1-cdcb73fb3959/images/f787f899-db4e-48d7-9c4c-fc7fb4e26e99/image.png)

Magnification: 100 x\hspace{3em}Scale bar = 10 µm[Source: Adapted from User: NEON. (2014).Chlorella vulgaris Beijerinck Nies-2170 / Olympus IX71+DP72.Wikimedia Common. Retrieved April 6, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Chlorella_vulgaris_NIES2170.jpg. Copyright by CC BY-SA 3.0]Which statement best explains how chlorophyll supports a function of life?A.\hspace{1em}It catalyses the breakdown of glucose into ATP.B.\hspace{1em}It absorbs light energy needed to convert inorganic molecules into organic molecules.C.\hspace{1em}It transports carbon dioxide into the chloroplast for glucose synthesis.D.\hspace{1em}It stores the energy released during cellular respiration.
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Baccurately describes chlorophyll’s role in photosynthesis, a process that supports the life function of nutrition in autotrophic organisms (like plants and some unicellular organisms). Chlorophyll absorbs light energy, which is used to convert inorganic carbon dioxide and water into the organic compound glucose.Choice Ais incorrect because this describes cellular respiration, not the function of chlorophyll.
The breakdown of glucose into ATP happens in the mitochondria and does not use chlorophyll.Choice Cis incorrect because chlorophyll does not transport carbon dioxide; CO₂ enters the leaf via stomata and diffuses into chloroplasts. Chlorophyll’s role is to absorb light, not transport gases.Choice Dis incorrect because chlorophyll is involved in capturing light energy, not in storing energy from respiration. Energy from respiration is stored in ATP, not in chlorophyll.

list.title: Question 14
list.content: Which of the following statements is true of fungal cell walls?A.\hspace{1em}They are composed of cellulose.B.\hspace{1em}Fungal cells do not have cell walls.C.\hspace{1em}They are composed of chitin.D.\hspace{1em}They are composed of peptidoglycan.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because fungal cell walls are primarily composed of chitin.Choice Ais incorrect because cellulose is the main carbohydrate that makes up plant cell walls. Peptidoglycan is found in bacterial cell walls, soChoice Dis incorrect. Fungal cells do have cell walls, soChoice Bis incorrect.

list.title: Question 15
list.content: Which of the following statements are true about the structure of cells?I.All cells contain cytoplasm enclosed by the plasma membrane.II.The microscope was important in understanding the structure of the cell.III.Prokaryotes do not have genetic material.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis true because all cells have cytoplasm enclosed by the plasma membrane.Statement IIis also true because the invention of the microscope made viewing structures within the cell easier.Statement IIIis false because all cells have genetic material. Eukaryotic cells have their genetic material inside of the nucleus, while prokaryotes have their genetic material in the nucleoid region.

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
Below is a micrograph of a bacterium,Marinomonas arctica, which is found in Arctic sea ice.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e4c4e564-261e-4307-9a32-e06985877dc5/images/c403239f-99bf-4c69-919f-90bc200a737a/BI1258.png)

[Source: Gulf of Alaska Seamounts expedition, 2019.Marinomonas arctica.jpg. Wikimedia. Retrieved, September 25th 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Marinomonas_arctica.jpg. Copyright under Public Domain]Which row contains features of prokaryotic cells such asMarinomonas arctica?RibosomesCell wallDNA associated with proteinsA.\hspace{1em}80SYesNoB.\hspace{1em}80SYesYesC.\hspace{1em}70SNoNoD.\hspace{1em}70SYesNo
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because bacteria are prokaryotes, and prokaryotes have 70S ribosomes and a cell wall; they do not have proteins associated with the DNA.Choice Ais incorrect because prokaryotes do not have 80S ribosomes.Choice Bis incorrect because prokaryotes do not have 80S ribosomes or proteins associated with DNA.Choice Cis incorrect because prokaryotes do have cell walls.

list.title: Question 17
list.content: Which statement(s) is/arenottrue of eukaryotic or prokaryotic cells?I.\hspace{1em}Prokaryotic cells have a compartmentalised structure.II.\hspace{.8em}Only eukaryotic cells have a Golgi apparatus.III.\hspace{.6em}Only eukaryotic cells have membrane-bound organelles.A.\hspace{1em}II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement IisNOTtrue of prokaryotic cells because they do not have compartmentalised structures. Compartmentalisation is a defining feature of eukaryotic cells, allowing them to carry out more complex and specialised functions.Statement IIis true of prokaryotic cells because they do not have a Golgi apparatus. The Golgi apparatus is a membrane-bound organelle, and only eukaryotic cells possess it.Statement IIIis true because membrane-bound organelles is a defining feature of eukaryotic cells. Prokaryotic cells lack membrane-bound organelles entirely.Choice Bis the correct answer as it only includesStatement I.Choices A, CandDare incorrect as they all includeStatement II,Statement IIIor both.

In the case of blood, these cellsdifferentiate into red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 19
list.content: Which statement applies to both mitochondria and prokaryotes?A.\hspace{1em}They both contain DNA.B.\hspace{1em}They both have flagella.C.\hspace{1em}They both contain lysosomes.D.\hspace{1em}They both have a cell wall.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Mitochondria and prokaryotes both contain their own DNA (Choice A).Choices B,CandDare incorrect as they are all only present in prokaryotes but not in mitochondria.

Royalty free image.]Identify structures X, Y, and Z in the micrograph.Structure XStructure YStructure ZA.\hspace{1em}mitochondrionnucleusplasma membraneB.\hspace{1em}chloroplastvacuolecell wallC.\hspace{1em}mitochondrionvacuoleplasma membraneD.\hspace{1em}chloroplastnucleuscell wall
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because structure X is a chloroplast, structure Y is the nucleus and structure Z is the cell wall.Choice Ais incorrect because X is a chloroplast, not a mitochondrion.Choice Bis incorrect because Y is the nucleus, not a vacuole.Choice Cis incorrect because both structures X and Y are mislabelled.

list.title: Question 22
list.content: Which structure is found in both eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells?A.\hspace{1em}LysosomeB.\hspace{1em}RibosomeC.\hspace{1em}Golgi apparatusD.\hspace{1em}Nucleoid
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Unlike eukaryotes, prokaryotes lack a nucleus and membrane-bound organelles. However, like eukaryotes, prokaryotes contain ribosomes, a non-membrane-bound organelle required for protein synthesis. So, ribosomes are found in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes.Lysosomes (Choice A) and the Golgi apparatus (Choice C) are only found in eukaryotes. The nucleoid (Choice D) is only found in prokaryotes.

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
What is the actual width of the cell in this image? The scale bar represents 5μm.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6b591b07-f59c-48c2-9596-d40067442d9b/images/bc4aab5d-8d13-40de-a819-a662fa2d63b0/BI1135.png)

[Source: Adapted from Itayba, Hebrew Wikipedia (2006, March 1).File: Electron Microscope Siemens, 1960.jpg - wikimedia commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved March 4, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_microscope_Siemens,_1960.jpg Copyright under CC BY 3.0]A.\hspace{1em}4μmB.\hspace{1em}40μmC.\hspace{1em}400μmD.\hspace{1em}4000μm
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The scale bar is shown to be 5μm in width, which is represented by 0.5cm on the ruler. The ruler indicates a total cell width of 4cm. Therefore, 8 scale bar widths will fit within the cell. Actual cell width = 8×\times×5μm = 40μm.Choices A, C, andDare incorrect.

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
Mesophyll cells are found in plants. Plant cells have unique characteristics that distinguish them from any other cell type.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/860825df-c83f-42a2-959f-858276f1b357/images/a1726d87-2824-4bf2-b6bb-b3a42c682716/BI0575.png)

[Source: Adapted from Zhang, N., Zhang, L., Zhao, L., Ren, Y., Cui, D., Chen, J., ... & Chen, F. (2017).iTRAQ and virus-induced gene silencing revealed three proteins involved in the cold response in bread wheat. Scientific reports, 7(1), 1-16.Retrieved March 27, 2022. From https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5548720/. Copyright under CC by 4.0]In the micrograph above, one of the cell parts is labelled X. What is the name of this structure?A.\hspace{1em}ChloroplastB.\hspace{1em}Central vacuoleC.\hspace{1em}Cell wallD.\hspace{1em}Starch granule
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice C- The cell wall is the outermost layer of plant cells just outside the plasma membrane.Chloroplasts (Choice A) are membrane-bound oval-shaped organelles (labelled Ch in the image) that are responsible for photosynthesis.The central vacuole (Choice B) is located in the centre of the cell, not towards the outside.  It is evident in the micrograph provided by the white, empty space in the middle of the cell.Starch granules (Choice D) are structures consisting of starch.  Their function is to store starch which is produced during photosynthesis. Starch granules are not visible in the micrgraph above.

Copyright under Public Domain]Explain how the structure of this cell is related to the function of the synthesis of proteins for release from the cell.[2]State why an electron microscope is needed to view the ultrastructure of the
acinar cells.[2]

Theribosomeson the rough endoplasmic reticulum are the site of thesynthesisof thepolypeptides(✓\checkmark✓) and thesepolypeptidesare thenfolded and modified into functional proteinsin thelumenof therough endoplasmic reticulum(✓\checkmark✓).Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​electron microscopes have a higher resolution than light microscopes[1]→\ce{ -> }​electron microscopes have a higher magnification than light microscopes[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Electron microscopes havehigher magnification(✓\checkmark✓) andhigher resolution(✓\checkmark✓)  than light microscopes, so they allow more detail to be seen in smaller objects.

list.title: Question 26
list.content: Which row correctly describes the DNA and chromosomes of Eubacteria cells?ShapeDNA with histonesNumber of chromosomes\hspace{1em}A.\hspace{1em}CircularYesMore than one\hspace{1em}B.\hspace{1em}LinearYesMore than one\hspace{1em}C.\hspace{1em}CircularNoOne\hspace{1em}D.\hspace{1em}LinearNoOne
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Eubacteria have a single chromosome composed of DNA and not associated with histones(Choice C).Choice Ais incorrect because prokaryotes' DNA is not associated with histones and they only have one chromosome.Choice Bis incorrect because prokaryotes do not have linear DNA, their DNA is not associated with histones, and they do not have more than one chromosome.Choice Dis incorrect because prokaryotic chromosomes are not linear.

list.title: Question 27
list.content: Cyanobacteria are prokaryotes that can perform photosynthesis. Which structural feature is common to both cyanobacteria and plant cells?A.\hspace{1em}ChloroplastB.\hspace{1em}Cell wallC.\hspace{1em}PiliD.\hspace{1em}Mitochondria
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Prokaryotes are one of the earliest organisms to have evolved the process of photosynthesis. Plant cells are eukaryotes that can also perform photosynthesis, but they evolved after prokaryotes. Some of the features that distinguish prokaryotes from plant cells (which are eukaryotes) are membrane-bound organelles such as chloroplasts (Choice A) and mitochondria (Choice D) which are present in plant cells but absent in prokaryotes. According to the endosymbiotic theory, cyanobacteria evolved into chloroplasts during the early evolutionary process of eukaryotic cells.Pili are found in prokaryotes but not in plant cells (Choice C). Even though the composition of the cell wall in prokaryotes is different (made of a peptidoglycan polymer) from the cell wall in plant cells (made up of cellulose), the presence of the cell wall is a common feature found in both prokaryotes and plant cells (Choice B).

list.title: Question 28
list.content: Which statement provides evidence for the endosymbiotic theory?A.\hspace{1em}Phospholipids readily form bilayers.B.\hspace{1em}Chloroplasts possess a double membrane.C.\hspace{1em}RNA is self-replicating.D.\hspace{1em}Mitochondria possess a single membrane.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The endosymbiotic theory states that larger prokaryotes engulfed smaller prokaryotes, which were the ancestors of modern chloroplasts and mitochondria. The smaller prokaryotes were engulfed via endocytosis, so they have their original membrane as well as the membrane of the larger prokaryote.Choice Bis correct.Choice Ais incorrect because it provides evidence for the evolution of plasma membranes not endosymbiotic theory.Choice Cis incorrect because it provides evidence for the mechanism of inheritance.Choice Dis incorrect because mitochondria have a double membrane.

list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais incorrect, as the photo shows an animal cell, which can contain smaller, single membraned vacuoles, but the nucleus is much larger.Choice Bis incorrect as lysosomes are smaller and have a single membrane.Choice Cis incorrect as nucleoids are only present in prokaryotes and are not membrane bound.

list.title: Question 30
list.content: Which of the following supports the theory that multicellularity has evolved repeatedly?I.Sexual reproduction is more common in multicellular organisms, allowing for greater genetic diversity.II.Modern eukaryotes are believed to have evolved from larger prokaryotes which engulfed but didn't digest beneficial smaller prokaryotes.III.Fossil evidence indicates that different taxa developed multicellularity at different times in evolutionary history.A.\hspace{1em}III onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Fossils provide evidence that different taxa developed multicellularity at different times in evolutionary history, indicating that multicellularity developed independently in different taxa;Statement IIIis correct.Choice Ais correct.Although multicellular organisms more commonly reproduce sexually than single-celled organisms, leading to greater genetic diversity, this does not directly support the idea of multicellularity evolving repeatedly. It highlights one of the advantages of sexual reproduction, however, single-celled organisms tend to reproduce rapidly by asexual reproduction, which can lead to more effective dispersal and the withstanding of harsher conditions.Statement Iis not true.Statement IIis not true as it summarises the theory of endosymbiosis rather than supports multicellularity evolving repeatedly.Choices B,CandDare incorrect, as they all containStatement IIand/orStatement III.

list.title: Question 31
list.content: What feature of chloroplasts provides evidence for the endosymbiotic theory?A.\hspace{1em}They have their own nucleus.B.\hspace{1em}They have a single membrane.C.\hspace{1em}They contain 70S ribosomes.D.\hspace{1em}They contain a thylakoid membrane.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The endosymbiotic theory states that larger prokaryotes engulfed smaller prokaryotes, which were the ancestors of modern chloroplasts and mitochondria. The smaller prokaryotes contained their own 70S ribosomes which were distinct from the host cell's 80S ribosomes.Choice Cis correct.Choices AandBare incorrect because chloroplasts do not have a nucleus and have a double membrane.Choice Dis incorrect because although chloroplasts do contain a thylakoid membrane, this is not evidence for the endosymbiotic theory.

list.title: Question 32
list.content: Which of the following statements read true for differences between prokaryotes and eukaryotes?I.Prokaryotes have DNA associated with histones, while eukaryotic cells have naked DNA.II.Eukaryotes have linear chromosomes, while prokaryotes have circular chromosomes.III.Most prokaryotes have a singular chromosome, whilst most eukaryotic somatic cells contain at least two chromosomes.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Prokaryotes typically have DNA that is not associated with histones and is often referred to as ‘naked’. In eukaryotes, histone proteins help package the DNA into structural units called nucleosomes. This makesStatement Ifalse.Eukaryotic chromosomes are typically linear and located within the nucleus, while most prokaryotic organisms have a single circular chromosome found in a nucleoid region without a surrounding nuclear membrane. This makesStatement IItrue.Most prokaryotes contain a single circular chromosome, while eukaryotic somatic cells are generally diploid with paired chromosomes. ThereforeStatement IIIis true.Seeming as onlyStatements IIandIIIare true, this makesChoice Bthe correct answer to the question.Choices A, CandDare all incorrect as they includeStatement I.

list.title: Question 33
list.content:
Match the labelled structure (Q-T from the diagram) with its primary structure.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/38b38de6-6717-482a-9a4f-f546274b7e7d/images/ce1af51c-d72e-48f9-8b0a-39700a6e5d99/Ed2790.png)

list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:In the diagram, T indicates naked DNA, and this is the genetic material for the cell. Q indicates the cell wall, which provides structural support and protection. R indicates the cell membrane, which regulates the passage of substances in and out of the cell, and S indicates the cytoplasm, which is the site of metabolic reactions in the cell. Therefore,Choice Cis the correct answer because it correctly matches the functions of the structures that are indicated by the letters in the diagram.Choice A, Choice B, andChoice Ddo not correctly match the functions of the structures indicated by the letters in the diagram.

list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The cell membrane of prokaryotes is surrounded by a rigid cell wall. The cell wall provides shape and structure to the organism. It also prevents the cell from bursting when the cell takes up water through osmosis.  The cell wall is located between the cell membrane and the capsule, a sticky outer layer of polysaccharide. The cell wall is shown in the image below.

list.title: Question 35
list.content: Which of the following options correctly identifies the forms of DNA and the types of ribosomes found in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells?Prokaryotic DNAEukaryotic DNAProkaryotic RibosomesEukaryotic RibosomesA.\hspace{1em}LinearCircular80S70SB.\hspace{1em}CircularLinear80S80SC.\hspace{1em}CircularLinear70S80SD.\hspace{1em}LinearLinear70S70S
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Prokaryotic cells have circular DNA and 70S ribosomes, while eukaryotic cells have linear DNA and 80S ribosomes. Therefore,Choice Cis correct.Choices A, BandDare incorrect because they do not have the correct combinations.

list.title: Question 36
list.content: Which process is most likely responsible for the origin of mitochondria as a eukaryotic cell organelle?A.\hspace{1em}OsmosisB.\hspace{1em}ExocytosisC.\hspace{1em}ApoptosisD.\hspace{1em}Endocytosis
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice A– Osmosis is an example of passive transport, which involves the movement of water across a semi-permeable membrane.Choice B- Exocytosis is an example of active transport that moves large molecules out of the cell to the cell’s exterior.Choice C– Apoptosis is the process of programmed cell death.Choice D- Endocytosis is an example of active transport that moves large molecules, parts of a cell, or a cell from the cell’s exterior, into a cell’s interior. This is in accordance with the endosymbiotic theory, which is the most likely process by which mitochondria came to be eukaryotic organelles.

Retrieved March 5, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Figure_04_00_00.jpg Copyright under CC by 3.0]A.\hspace{1em}They are multinucleate.B.\hspace{1em}They only have one nucleus.C.\hspace{1em}They have unusually large cells that contain only one nucleus.D.\hspace{1em}They contain mitochondria.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Fungal hyphae and striated muscle are both exceptions to the cell theory as they are much larger than typical cells and are multinucleate.Choice Bis incorrect as the diagrams depict onion epidermis cells and mast cells, which each contain one nucleus.Choice Cis incorrect as both fungal hyphae and striated muscles contain multiple nuclei.Choice Dis incorrect as fungal hyphae, striated muscle AND the cells in the diagram all contain mitochondria.

list.title: Question 39
list.content: Which of the following correctly pairs the structure with the type of cell in which it is found?StructureType of cellA.\hspace{1em}Nucleoid regionAnimalB.\hspace{1em}Cell wallProkaryoticC.\hspace{1em}ChloroplastFungal cellD.\hspace{1em}Sap vacuoleProkaryotic
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because nearly all prokaryotic cells possess a cell wall that provides structure, support, and protection.Choice Ais incorrect because a nucleoid region is characteristic of a prokaryotic cell, not an animal cell.Choice Cis incorrect because chloroplasts are found in plants and some algae cells, but not fungi.Choice Dis incorrect because sap vacuoles are characteristic of plant cells, not prokaryotic cells.

list.title: Question 40
list.content: Which of the following rows correctly pairs the cell type with its nuclear characteristic?Cell typeNuclear stateA.\hspace{1em}Phloem sieve tube elementsNo nucleusB.\hspace{1em}Skeletal muscle cellsSingle nucleusC.\hspace{1em}Red blood cellsSingle nucleusD.\hspace{1em}Aseptate fungal hyphaeNo nucleus
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because phloem sieve tube elements lose their nucleus as they mature to facilitate the transport of sugars.Choice Bis incorrect because skeletal muscle cells are multinucleated to accommodate their length.Choice Cis incorrect because mature red blood cells lack a nucleus. They jettison the nucleus when mature to increase the haemoglobin capacity of oxygen transport.Choice Dis incorrect because aseptate fungal hyphae have a continuous cytoplasm containing many nuclei.

list.markScheme: Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​surface area affects the rate at which materials enter and leave the cell[1]→\ce{ -> }​volume affects the rate at which materials are used and produced by the cell[1]→\ce{ -> }​the surface area to volume ratio affects the rate of metabolism in a cell[1]→\ce{ -> }​the bigger the cell, the smaller the SAratio is[1]→\ce{ -> }​cells having a low SAratio cannot exchange materials fast enough[1]→\ce{ -> }​some cells,ORmotor neurons,ORmuscle cells,ORother named example in humans, are long and thin, which maintains a high SAratio[1][4 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Thesurface areaof a cell affects the rate at which materialsenter and leave cells(✓\checkmark✓). On the other hand, the cell’svolumeaffects the rate at which materials areused and produced(✓\checkmark✓). A small surface area to volume ratio is not ideal for human cells because itlimits the cell’s ability to export waste from the cytoplasmrapidly enough to meet thecytoplasm’s metabolic needs, such as the availability of oxygen(✓\checkmark✓).A large cell has a small surface area to volume ratio(✓\checkmark✓). Therefore, the transport of the substances is more efficient in small cells.Anyfourof the following (function of life must be mentioned when explaining howParameciumperforms this, to award mark):→\ce{ -> }​functions of life are metabolismANDgrowthANDreproductionANDnutritionANDhomeostasisANDmovementANDexcretionANDresponse to stimuli,ORsensitivity[1]→\ce{ -> }​movement inParameciumis demonstrated by cilia used to propel themselves through water[1]→\ce{ -> }​response is through reacting to stimuli in the environmentORavoidance of light[1]→\ce{ -> }​homeostasis is demonstrated by keeping the internal conditions within set limitsORexcess water is expelled by the contractile vacuole[1]→\ce{ -> }​metabolism is carried out by enzymes in the cytoplasm[1]→\ce{ -> }​growth is an irreversible increase in sizeORdry mass and paramecium achieve this  through accumulating organic matterORnutrients from food[1]→\ce{ -> }​reproduction function inParameciumis demonstrated by asexual division through binary fission,ORmitosis or micronucleus and amitotic division of macronucleusORsexually through conjugation[1]→\ce{ -> }​excretion is the removal of metabolic waste products from the cellORdiffusion of CO2out of the cell[1]→\ce{ -> }​nutrition is performed by ingesting smaller organisms and digesting them in vesiclesORthrough endocytosis[1][4 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Parameciumacquiresnutrientsby ingesting bacteria anddigesting them in vesicles(✓\checkmark✓). It exhibitsgrowthwhen itirreversibly increases in sizeby accumulating organic matter from ingestedfood(✓\checkmark✓).Parameciumrespondsto different environmental stimuli. For example, itchangesthedirectionof its movement once ittouchesa solid object (✓\checkmark✓).ExcretioninParameciumoccurs when waste products such ascarbon dioxide diffuse out of the cell(✓\checkmark✓).Parameciumreproducesboth asexually bybinary fission(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 46
list.content: Which statements about unicellular and multicellular organisms are correct?Unicellular organismsMulticellular organismsA.\hspace{1em}They only reproduce asexuallyContains differentiated cellsB.\hspace{1em}Consist of only one cellAll cellular processes are carried out by one organelleC.\hspace{1em}Can reproduce sexuallyThey have emergent propertiesD.\hspace{1em}Contains differentiated cellsCan reproduce sexually
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais incorrect, as not all unicellular organisms reproduce asexually.Choice Bis incorrect, as both unicellular and multicellular organisms contain multiple organelles that carry out different functions.Choice Dis incorrect, because unicellular organisms do not contain more than one cell, and so do not contain multiple differentiated cells.

[Source: Adapted from Lewis, M. E., Belland, R. J., AbdelRahman, Y. M., Beatty, W. L., Aiyar, A. A., Zea, A. H., Greene, S. J., Marrero, L., Buckner, L. R., Tate, D. J., McGowin, C. L., Kozlowski, P. A., O’Brien, M., Lillis, R. A., Martin, D. H., & Quayle, A. J. (2014, May 15). Morphologic and molecular evaluation of chlamydia trachomatis growth in human endocervix reveals distinct growth patterns. Frontiers. Retrieved February 11 , 2024, from https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fcimb.2014.00071/full. Copyright free]\hspace{1em}Type of cell\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Process\hspace{1em}A.\hspace{1em}EukaryoticMitosisB.\hspace{1em}EukaryoticBinary fissionC.\hspace{1em}ProkaryoticMitosisD.\hspace{1em}ProkaryoticBinary fission
list.markScheme: DSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Prokaryotic cells have an approximate diameter of 0.1−-−5.0  µm, whereas eukaryotic cells are significantly larger with a diameter range of 10−-−100  µm.  The cells in the micrograph have an approximate diameter of 0.5  µm, so are prokaryotic. Prokaryotic cells do not replicate themselves using mitosis, they use binary fission.Choice Dis correct.Choices AandBare incorrect as the cells in the micrograph are prokaryotic, not eukaryotic.Choice Cis incorrect as prokaryotic cells lack a mitotic spindle, so do not carry out mitosis, they carry out binary fission.

Created with BioRender.com]Label the cartilage with the letter X.[1]State the name and role of the fluid found within this type of joint.[1]State one way in which skeletal muscle fibres are exceptions to the cell theory.[1]The contractile proteins actin and myosin in skeletal muscle fibres bring about movement of this joint. Explain how two other proteins within these cells, along with calcium, control the contraction of skeletal muscle.[3]
list.markScheme:
→\ce{ -> }​cartilage must be labelled with an X at the end of either bone[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/05754fea-41d1-4915-aad1-882ade1c9e5b/images/8846f3ce-713c-4b53-aedc-4aebff966c5e/BI1408AnsA.png)

[© Revision Village 2024. Created with BioRender.com]→\ce{ -> }​synovial fluidANDlubricates the jointsORprevents friction between bones[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The fluid within this type of joint is calledsynovial fluidand itlubricatesthe joint (✓\checkmark✓).Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​multinucleated[1]→\ce{ -> }​much largerORlonger than most cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​formed through fusion of multiple cells[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:They aremultinucleated(✓\checkmark✓).Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​tropomyosin winds around actin, covering myosin-binding sitesORtropomyosin covers binding sites on actin[1]→\ce{ -> }​troponin bound to tropomyosin helps maintain position of tropomyosin on actin filament[1]→\ce{ -> }​action potentialORstimulation of muscle fibre by nerve impulse causes calcium ions to be released from sarcoplasmic reticulum[1]→\ce{ -> }​calcium ions bind to troponin, causing it to change shapeORbringing about conformational change[1]→\ce{ -> }​troponin bound to calcium ions moves tropomyosin away from myosin-binding sites allowing myosin to bind to actin[1]→\ce{ -> }​when no stimulation of muscle fibreORno action potential along sarcoplasm, calcium ions are actively pumped back into sarcoplasmic reticulum[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The proteintropomyosinis coiled around actin filaments,coveringthemyosin-binding sites(✓\checkmark✓), and thereby preventing myosin forming cross bridges with the actin. Upon the arrival of anaction potential,calcium ionsarereleased fromthesarcoplasmic reticulum(✓\checkmark✓).  These calcium ions thenbindtotroponin, a proteinassociated withbothactin and tropomyosin, ((✓\checkmark✓). The binding of calcium ions totroponininduces aconformational change(✓\checkmark✓) in the protein, which in turn causestropomyosintoshift away frommyosin-binding sites. Consequently, themyosinheads are now free tobindtoactin(✓\checkmark✓), enabling muscle contraction to occur.

list.title: Question 49
list.content: Distinguish between a colony of algal cells forming a multicellular sphere, and a multicellular plant such as a water lily.[3]Draw a labelled diagram which shows the structure of an animal cell.[5]Describe the evidence for the endosymbiotic theory.[7]
list.markScheme:
Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​colony of algal cells are generally undifferentiatedWHEREASmulticellular plants like water lilies are composed of different typesORdifferentiated of cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​noORminimal organisationORminimal division of labour of cells in algal colony,WHEREASin multicellular plant cells arranged into tissues, organs and organ systems,ORwell-defined structures carry out specific roles in plants[1]→\ce{ -> }​each individual algal cell is capable of performing all necessary functions for lifeORsurvival independentlyWHEREASmost individual cells of multicellular plants cannot survive independentlyORaway from the main body of the plant[1]→\ce{ -> }​each algal cell in a colony is genetically distinct,WHEREASnearly all cells in a multicellular organism are genetically identical[1]→\ce{ -> }​development of colonies is often simpleORcells simply join existing colonyWHEREASplants undergo complex developmental processes[1]→\ce{ -> }​reproduction in an algal colony typically involves asexual methodsWHEREASin multicellular plants such as the water lily typically involves sexual reproductionORmulticellular plants use both sexual and asexual reproduction[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Unlike true multicellular organisms like water lilies, algal colonieslack cellular differentiationandspecialised tissues.Individual cellswithin the colony aregenetically distinctand largelyindependent, being able to perform allvital functions. In contrast, most cells in themulticellularplant aregenetically identical(✓\checkmark✓) and usuallydo not survivewhenseparatedfrom the plant (✓\checkmark✓). These cells becomespecialised(✓\checkmark✓) and formtissues, organs, andorgan systemswithin the plant. This intricatedivision of labour(✓\checkmark✓) allows plants to achieve greater size and complexity.Anyfourof the following labelled correctly in an appropriate drawing of an animal cell:→\ce{ -> }​nucleus (shown with double membrane)[1]→\ce{ -> }​cytoplasm[1]→\ce{ -> }​cellORplasma membrane[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondrion[1]→\ce{ -> }​ribosome[1]→\ce{ -> }​golgi apparatus[1]→\ce{ -> }​rough endoplasmic reticulum[1]→\ce{ -> }​smooth endoplasmic reticulum[1]→\ce{ -> }​lysosome[1]and the following:→\ce{ -> }​diagram drawn without sketchy lines and acceptable size[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1ff31851-24a7-4efc-b3a3-080da5df9c59/images/efb7b494-b22f-41fc-8c24-c635f2f9bcac/BI1050.png)

[© Revision Village 2022]Anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​larger prokaryotesORcells engulfed smaller prokaryotesORcells[1]→\ce{ -> }​ingested cell was kept alive[1]→\ce{ -> }​symbiotic relationship between both cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​ingested cell acquired a second membrane[1]→\ce{ -> }​ingested cell is ancestor of chloroplastsORmitochondria[1]→\ce{ -> }​chloroplastORmitochondrial structures provide evidence for the endosymbiotic theory[1]→\ce{ -> }​chloroplastsORmitochondria contain 70S ribosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​chloroplastsORmitochondria contain their own DNAORlooped DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​chloroplastsORmitochondria can conduct transcriptionORtranslation[1]→\ce{ -> }​chloroplastsORmitochondria divide in a similar manner to prokaryotic cellsORby binary fission[1]→\ce{ -> }​chloroplastsORmitochondria are similar in size to prokaryotes[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The endosymbiotic theory explains the origin of some structures in eukaryotic cells, including chloroplasts and mitochondria. Theancestorsof chloroplasts and mitochondria were prokaryotes thatwere engulfed by larger prokaryotes(✓\checkmark✓).  The ingested cells werekept alive(✓\checkmark✓) and both cells eventually developed asymbioticrelationship (✓\checkmark✓) with the cell that engulfed them. When the larger cells engulfed the smaller cells, the smaller cells gained asecond membrane(✓\checkmark✓) as they were engulfed via endocytosis. Further evidence for the theory is that chloroplasts and mitochondria contain their own70s ribosomes(✓\checkmark✓) so canmake their own proteins, and also containtheir own DNA(✓\checkmark✓) so can carry outtranscription(✓\checkmark✓). Chloroplasts and mitochondria are also able todivide in a similar manner to prokaryotic cells(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 52
list.content: Which statements about chloroplasts and mitochondria support the endosymbiotic theory?ChloroplastsMitochondria\hspace{1em}A.\hspace{1em}Contain 70S ribosomesContain cristae\hspace{1em}B.\hspace{1em}Found in prokaryotesContain 80S ribosomes\hspace{1em}C.\hspace{1em}Have a single membraneContain circular DNA\hspace{1em}D.\hspace{1em}Contain 70S ribosomesHave a double membrane
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The endosymbiotic theory states that larger prokaryotes engulfed smaller prokaryotes, which were the ancestors of modern chloroplasts and mitochondria. The smaller prokaryotes were engulfed via endocytosis, so they have their original membrane as well as the membrane of the larger prokaryote.   Both chloroplasts and mitochondria have 70S ribosomes and a double membrane.Choice Dis correct.Choice Ais incorrect because the fact that mitochondria contain cristae is not due to the endosymbiotic theory.Choice Bis incorrect because chloroplasts are not found in prokaryotes.Choice Cis incorrect because chloroplasts have a double membrane.

list.title: Question 53
list.content: Outline the steps in calculating the magnification of a micrograph.[4]Describe the steps taken to focus on a specimen using the 40x objective lens of a light microscope.[4]
list.markScheme: Anyfourof the following:→\ce{->}​measure (using a ruler) the scale bar on the drawingORmicrograph[1]→\ce{->}​note the stated length which the scale bar represents[1]→\ce{->}​convert the represented and real length or scale bar into the same units[1]→\ce{->}​M= I/AORany correct example of the calculation[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:To calculate the magnification of a microphotograph, the first step is to measurethe scale bar using a ruler(✓\checkmark✓). The second step isto note the length the scale bar represents(✓\checkmark✓). This gives you the actual size of the image. These two measurements should be converted tothe same units(✓\checkmark✓). The last step is todivide the length measured by the ruler by the length represented by the scale bar(✓\checkmark✓). During this calculation, units cancel out.  Therefore, themagnification does not have units.Anyfourof the following:→\ce{->}​use the lowest powerOR4X objective lens first[1]→\ce{->}​place the specimenORslide directly below the objective lensORon the centre of the microscope stage[1]→\ce{->}​turn the coarse focus knob to focus on the specimen at 4X[1]→\ce{->}​adjust the turretORchange the objective lens so the medium powerOR10X objective lens is used[1]→\ce{->}​refocus on the specimen using a fine focus knob at 10X and 40X[1]→\ce{->}​adjust the turretORchange the objective lens, so the high powerOR40X objective lens is used[1]→\ce{->}​while fine focusing always move the lens away from the slide[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Place the specimenin the centreof the microscope stage  (✓\checkmark✓).  Use the4x objective lens first(✓\checkmark✓) and use thecoarse focus knob(✓\checkmark✓) to focus on the specimen.  Adjust the position of the specimen so it is in the middle of the field of view and thenswitch to the 10x(✓\checkmark✓) objective lens andrefocus using the fine focus knob, (✓\checkmark✓) by moving lensaway from the specimen(✓\checkmark✓) to prevent lens breakage.  Finally, switch to the40x objective lens(✓\checkmark✓) and use thefine focus knobto refocus on the specimen.

list.content:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c3dfa29a-d486-40b4-9fc1-d44b66ce3fc7/images/937853fc-bf32-495b-aba7-33e0cf82a199/BI1197-SL.png)

Copyright under CCO]Using your knowledge and the micrograph, state two features that would indicate that this is a bacterium.[2]Outline the structural differences between animal and plant cells.[3]Explain how light energy is used in photosynthesis to carry out anabolic reactions.[3]
list.markScheme: Anytwoof the following→\ce{ -> }​cell wall of peptidoglycan[1]→\ce{ -> }​naked DNAORDNA not associated with histonesORproteins[1]→\ce{ -> }​nucleoidORDNA free in cytoplasm[1]→\ce{ -> }​no membrane bound organelles[1]→\ce{ -> }​70s ribosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​cell smaller than 10μm[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Two features that would indicate that this is a bacterium are it hasno membrane-bound organelles(✓\checkmark✓) and70s ribosomes(✓\checkmark✓).Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​plant cells have a cell wall,WHEREASanimal cells do not[1]→\ce{ -> }​plant cells generally have a central vacuoleWHEREASanimal cells do not[1]→\ce{ -> }​plant cells have chloroplastsWHEREASanimal cells do not[1]→\ce{ -> }​animal cells may have lysosomesWHEREASplant cells do not[1]→\ce{ -> }​animal cells may have ciliaORflagellaWHEREASplant cells do not[1]→\ce{ -> }​animal cells have centriolesWHEREASplant cells do not[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Plant cells have acell wall, central vacuoleandchloroplasts, whereasanimalcellsdo not(✓\checkmark✓) (✓\checkmark✓) (✓\checkmark✓).Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​light energy is absorbed by chlorophyll[1]→\ce{ -> }​light energy is transferred to electronsORis used to excite electrons[1]→\ce{ -> }​light energy splitting water moleculesORphotolysis releases electrons for the electron transport chainORhydrogen ions for use in ATP production[1]→\ce{ -> }​light energy is used to synthesise ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphateORNADPH from electrons and one proton[1]→\ce{ -> }​NADPHORATP is used to make larger organic compoundsORglucoseORstarchORother named organic compound from carbon dioxide[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Light energy isabsorbedbychlorophyll(✓\checkmark✓) and is used toexcite electrons(✓\checkmark✓).  These electrons reduceNADP+to formNADPH, which is an anabolic reaction (✓\checkmark✓).  Energy present inNADPHis then used toproduce glucosefromcarbon dioxide(✓\checkmark✓).  This is also an anabolic reaction.

list.title: Question 55

[© Revision Village 2025. Created in BioRender.com]Which row correctly pairs each cell with its type?Cell XCell YCell ZA.\hspace{1em}Palisade mesophyllYeastLiverB.\hspace{1em}LiverPalisade mesophyllYeastC.\hspace{1em}YeastLiverPalisade mesophyllD.\hspace{1em}Palisade mesophyllLiverYeast
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Cell Xis undergoing budding, a process characteristic of unicellular fungi like yeast. The cell also has a cell wall, a large vacuole and no chloroplasts, reinforcing that this cell is indeed a fungal cell, such as yeast.Cell Yhas no cell wall, no visible vacuoles and there are centrioles in the dividing cells, indicating that this is a dividing animal cell, such as a liver cell.Cell Zhas is dividing into daughter cells, each of which has a cell wall, vacuole, and chloroplasts. The cell is also dividing evenly by laying down a cell plate between the cells, which will develop into the cell walls of the new cells. These are all features of plant cells, such as palisade mesophyll cells.Choice Cis therefore the correct answer to this question.

list.title: Question 56
list.content:
The figure below shows the results of a study on the evolution of multicellularity. Obligate multicellularity means the organism is always multicellular, facultative multicellularity means the organism is usually unicellular but can sometimes form multicellular structures.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e940829b-1b89-44cf-8a66-34d55df8cf92/images/6b245b5b-8c5e-4ec0-ad11-47b0515ebe5a/Ed2727.png)

[Source: Adapted from Fisher, R. (2013).Group Formation, Relatedness, and the Evolution of Multicellularity. Current Biology, 23. Retrieved April 2025  from https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0960982213005678. CC BY 3.0.]What can be deduced from this phylogenetic tree?I.All mammals are obligately multicellularII.Multicellularity evolved once in eukaryotesIII.All prokaryotes are unicellularA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and IIC.\hspace{1em}I and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis true because mammals are animals, and from the phylogenetic tree, the word animals is boxed(obligately multicellular).Statement IIis false because multicellularity appears on multiple separate branches that do not share a recent common ancestor, suggesting independent evolution.Statement IIIis false because cyanobacteria are prokaryotes, and the tree shows them boxed, indicating they are multicellular.Therefore,Choice Ais correct as it only contains the one trueStatement I.Choices B, C, andDare all incorrect as they include one or more of the falseStatements IIandIII.

list.title: Question 58
list.content: The table below compares two specialised cells found in the human body:Cell TypePrimary FunctionProteins ExpressedSkeletal MuscleMovementActin & MyosinNeuronCommunicationNeurotransmitters & Ion Channel ProteinsWhich of the following explains the differences between the specialised cells?A.\hspace{1em}Muscle cells and neurons have different DNA, so they produce different proteinsB.\hspace{1em}Each cell type expresses only the genes needed for its functionC.\hspace{1em}Differentiation permanently deletes unused genes from a cell’s DNAD.\hspace{1em}Neurons and muscle cells switch functions over time, depending on environmental conditions
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct. Each cell type expresses only the genes needed for its function, while other genes remain inactive. This selective gene expression leads to structural and functional differences between cells.Choice Ais incorrect. All cells in an organism (except gametes and red blood cells) contain the same DNA. Differences in protein production result from differences in gene expression, not in DNA sequence.Choice Cis incorrect. Differentiation silences genes but does not remove them.Choice Dis incorrect. Once differentiated, cells do not differentiate again — a neuron will not become a muscle cell later in life.

list.title: Question 59
list.content: Which statement(s) provide evidence for the endosymbiotic theory?I.\hspace{1.6em}Mitochondria and chloroplasts have adaptations that increase their surface areaII.\hspace{1.3em}Mitochondria and chloroplasts can make ATPIII.\hspace{1em}Mitochondria and chloroplasts have their own ribosomesA.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The endosymbiotic theory explains that modern eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells, when larger prokaryotes engulfed, but did not digest, other prokaryotes that are the precursors of modern chloroplasts and mitochondria. Evidence for this includes mitochondria and chloroplasts being the only organelles in eukaryotes that have their own ribosomes (Statement III).Choice Bis correct.Statement Iis incorrect as the adaptations that increase the surface area of mitochondria and chloroplasts are not evidence for endosymbiosis.Statement IIis incorrect as before they were engulfed, the ancient prokaryotic precursors to mitochondria and chloroplasts had the ability to generate ATP, so this ability was not acquired as a result of endosymbiosis.Choices A, CandDare incorrect as they containStatements Iand/orII.

list.title: Question 61
list.content: The plasma membrane, a structure common to all cells, is primarily composed of a phospholipid bilayer. What is the fundamental reason for this specific lipid arrangement?A.\hspace{1em}To provide a flexible boundary for the cell and a source of stored energy.B.\hspace{1em}To create a rigid barrier impermeable to most substances for protection.C.\hspace{1em}To form a selectively permeable barrier due to the hydrophobic nature of the lipids.D.\hspace{1em}To actively transport molecules using energy from the lipids.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because it accurately describes the plasma membrane as selectively permeable, allowing some things to pass and some not, and this is because the tails of the phospholipids comprising the membrane are hydrophobic.Choice Ais incorrect. While it’s true that the membrane provides a flexible boundary for the cell, it is not a source of energy. If the membrane is broken down to release energy, the boundary of the cell will be destroyed, and the cell will cease to exist.Choice Bis incorrect because the membrane is not rigid or impermeable. It is flexible and partially permeable.Choice Dis incorrect because the energy used to transport molecules across the membrane is typically provided by the hydrolysis of ATP.

They differentiate or become specialised during their development due to the expression of some genes but not others (Statement II).Statement IIIis not true because although both types of cells originate from stem cells, they come from different lineages and therefore develop from different stem cell populations or niches.Choices B, C, andDare incorrect because they containStatement III.

list.title: Question 63
list.content: Outline the different uses of karyograms.[3]Distinguish between cells with haploid and diploid nuclei.[4]Compare and contrast different types of chromosomes.[8]
list.markScheme:
Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​karyograms are images of the chromosomes in an organism[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs of decreasing length OR Sex chromosomes are the 23rd pair in human karyograms[1]→\ce{ -> }​karyograms can be used to identify the sex of an individual[1]→\ce{ -> }​karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy, e.g. Down syndromeORPatau syndromeORKlinefelter syndrome[1]→\ce{ -> }​karyograms can be used to determine if a chromosome is missingORif part of a chromosome is missing[1][3 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Karyograms(✓\checkmark✓) are images of the chromosomes in an organism. In a karyogram, the pairs of homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs ofdecreasing length(✓\checkmark✓). The sex chromosomes are shown as the 23rd pair in human karyograms.
Karyograms can be used to determine if an individual is a biologicalmale or female(✓\checkmark✓). Two X chromosomes are present in a human female cell, and one X chromosome and one Y chromosome are present in a human male cell.
Karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy (three copies of a chromosome) e.g.Down syndrome, Patau syndrome, Edward’s syndrome and Klinefelter syndrome).Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​haploid nuclei have one set of chromosomes,ORone chromosome per typeWHEREASdiploid nuclei have two setsORtwo chromosomes of each type[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid nuclei have one allele for each geneWHEREASdiploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid nuclei in humans have 23 chromosomes, and diploid nuclei in humans have 46 chromosomesORany other valid species example[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid cells are usually gametesWHEREASdiploid cells are usually somatic cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid cells are usually the result of meiosis,WHILEdiploid cells are usually the result of mitosis.[1][4 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Haploid nuclei haveone set of chromosomes(✓\checkmark✓), whereas diploid nuclei have two sets of chromosomes.  For example, inhumans(✓\checkmark✓), gametes have 23 chromosomes, while somatic cells have 46 chromosomes. Haploid nuclei haveone allele for each gene, (✓\checkmark✓)  whereas diploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene. In humans, onlygametes(✓\checkmark✓)  have haploid nuclei, whereas the rest of the somatic cells have diploid nuclei.Anyeightof the following:→\ce{ -> }​(within one species) different chromosomes are composed of DNA molecules with different lengths[1]→\ce{ -> }​(within one species) different chromosomes have different numbers of genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​(within one species) different chromosomes have different typesORdifferent numbers of genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​both prokaryoticANDeukaryotic chromosomes contain DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins,WHILEeukaryotic and archaeal chromosomes are associated with proteins[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic chromosomes are looped molecules of DNA,WHILEeukaryotic chromosomes are linear molecules of DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHautosomes and sex chromosomes contain genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​the human Y chromosome carries information mainly coding for male sex determination and development,WHILEthe X chromosome carries information for other body characteristics[1]→\ce{ -> }​there is only one pair of sex chromosomes,WHILEthere can be more than one pair of autosomes (in different species)[1]→\ce{ -> }​autosomes are pairs of homologous chromosomes of equal length,WHILEtwo sex chromosomes can be different lengths[1]→\ce{ -> }​chromosomes can be homologous and non-homologous[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes of equal length carrying the same genes, but different alleles,WHILEnon-homologous chromosomes, carry different genes[1][8 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:All chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes, but theydiffer in length(✓\checkmark✓) and in thenumber of genes(✓\checkmark✓) andtype of genes(✓\checkmark✓). Similarities and differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomes: Both prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomescontain DNA(✓\checkmark✓). Bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins, but eukaryotic chromosomes areassociated with proteins(✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotic chromosomes are looped, while eukaryotic chromosomes arelinear(✓\checkmark✓).Similarities and differences between autosomes and sex chromosomes:Both autosomes and sex chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes. Autosomes are chromosomes that do not determine sex and do not have genes for sex-linked characteristics; sex chromosomes determine sex and have genes for sex-linked traits. There is one pair of sex chromosomes in a somatic nucleus, but there can bemore than one pair of autosomes(✓\checkmark✓) in a somatic nucleus. X and Y chromosomes are of different lengths, while autosomal homologous chromosome pairs areequal in length(✓\checkmark✓)Comparing non-homologous chromosomes and homologous chromosomes:Homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes that have genes for the same characteristics and can have the same or different alleles. Non-homologous chromosomes have genes fordifferent characteristics(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

It is likely a prokaryotic cell.Entity Xis only reported to have RNA with a protein coat surrounding it. This description best matches that of a virus. Viruses are not considered living organisms.Entity Ycontains membrane-bound compartments, which are indicative of eukaryotic organelles and DNA. This description is likely describing a eukaryotic cell.Entity Zis only DNA without any barrier to the outside and does not describe a cell.Choice Ais correct because it correctly identifiesEntities WandYas likely to be classified as living, whileXandZ are classifiedas non-living.Choice B, Choice C, andChoice Ddo not have this combination of entities.

list.title: Question 66
list.content: Palisade mesophyll cells produce and release large amounts of carbohydrates. Which characteristics would you expect to observe in such cells?A.\hspace{1em}A high density of mitochondria and a large central vacuole.B.\hspace{1em}A high density of chloroplasts and an extensive Golgi apparatus.C.\hspace{1em}A high density of chloroplasts and a large central vacuole.D.\hspace{1em}A high density of mitochondria and an extensive Golgi apparatus.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Palisade mesophyll cells are cells in the leaves of plants that produce carbohydrates through photosynthesis. Since photosynthesis takes place within chloroplasts, these cells contain a high density of chloroplasts They also contain a large central vacuole, which occupies the space at the center of the cell and helps maintain the turgor pressure in the cell. The position of the central vacuole ensures the chloroplasts will be pushed near the edges of the cell, where they can receive light. Additionally, the vacuole acts as a storage reservoir for water and other nutrients needed for photosynthesis.Choice AandChoice Dare incorrect because mitochondria are the site of aerobic respiration, during which carbohydrates are broken down to produce ATP.Choice Dis also incorrect as the Golgi apparatus packages proteins, not carbohydrates, for export, soChoice Bis also incorrect.

[Source: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)/NIH (2019, January 4).Electron micrograph of tau clusters (46603522841).jpg. Wikimedia. Retrieved December 27, 2024, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_micrograph_of_tau_clusters_(46603522841).jpg. Public Domain]Which of these methods is used to analyse protein structure?A.\hspace{1em}Freeze-fracture electron microscopyB.\hspace{1em}Fluorescent stainingC.\hspace{1em}Cryogenic electron microscopyD.\hspace{1em}Immunofluorescence
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because cryogenic electron microscopy can produce 3D images of biological molecules such as proteins, DNA, and RNA. Samples are rapidly frozen to preserve their natural state before an electron beam is passed through, allowing the structure of individual molecules to be studied.Choice Ais incorrect because freeze-fracture electron microscopy is primarily used to study cellular structures, such as the internal arrangement of membranes. While it involves rapid freezing and can produce 3D images, it does not resolve molecular or atomic details of protein structures.Choice Bis incorrect because fluorescent staining is used in light microscopy to identify specific molecules, such as proteins, in cells. Fluorescent dyes or antibodies emit specific wavelengths of light, highlighting target molecules, but they do not provide detailed structural information about proteins.Choice Dis incorrect because immunofluorescence identifies specific proteins in cells or tissues using fluorescently tagged antibodies. While it is useful for locating proteins, it is not a technique for analysing protein structure at the molecular level.

list.content: Outline one way unicellular organisms can carry out each of nutrition, movement and excretion.[3]Draw a single mitochondrion, and annotate it to outline the role of four labelled structures.[5]Compare and contrast the structure of E. coli and a palisade mesophyll cell.[7]
list.markScheme:
Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​nutrition by diffusion through cell membraneORengulfmentORphagocytosisORendocytosisORphotosynthesisORdigestion by enzymes in vacuoles[1]→\ce{ -> }​movement by ciliaORflagellaORpseudopodia[1]→\ce{ -> }​excretion by  simple diffusionORactive transportORexocytosisORcontractile vacuolesORvacuoles storingORisolating waste before removal[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Unicellular organisms carry out the processes of life in varying ways. They can carry outnutritionbyengulfingthe nutrients (✓\checkmark✓) from their surroundings, they canmoveusingflagella(✓\checkmark✓), and they canremove wastesfrom the cell bysimple diffusion(✓\checkmark✓).Diagram must include four of the following labels and annotations:→\ce{ -> }​outer membrane protective barrierORcontains transport proteins that allow specific molecules to enter the mitochondrion[1]→\ce{ -> }​inner membraneORcristae increase surface area for reactionsORcontains proteins essential for reactionsORATP production[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA encodes genes essential for mitochondrial functioning[1]→\ce{ -> }​70S ribosomes for synthesis of proteins required by mitochondrion[1]→\ce{ -> }​matrix contains enzymes for chemical reactions[1]→\ce{ -> }​intermembrane space - allows build-up of protonsORion gradient for ATP synthesisORchemiosmosisORcontains enzymes for chemical reactions[1]→\ce{ -> }​clear drawing with no sketchy lines and of suitable size[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ba177021-8efc-4ac3-8984-af65f603bc24/images/51530aa5-3ec2-45cc-8701-1d4b4fd4ec74/BI1049.png)

[© Revision village 2022]Anysevenof the following (must contain at least one similarity and/or one difference):→\ce{ -> }​BOTHE.coliand palisade mesophyll cells have cellORplasma membranes[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHE.coliand palisade mesophyll cells have cytoplasm[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHE.coliand palisade mesophyll cells have a cell wall[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHE.coliand palisade mesophyll cells contain ribosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​E.colicell wall is made up of peptidoglycanWHEREASpalisade mesophyll cell walls are made of cellulose[1]→\ce{ -> }​palisade mesophyll cells have a compartmentalised structureWHEREASE.colido not[1]→\ce{ -> }​palisade mesophyll cells have 80S ribosomesWHEREASE.colihave 70S[1]→\ce{ -> }​palisade mesophyll cells have nucleiWHEREASE.colihave a nucleoid[1]→\ce{ -> }​E.colican have plasmidsORcircular DNAWHEREASpalisade mesophyll cells have linear DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​E.colihave external structures such as flagellaORpiliBUTpalisade mesophyll cells do not[1]→\ce{ -> }​palisade mesophyll cells have membrane bound organelles such as golgi apparatus, rough endoplasmic reticulum, chloroplasts, mitochondriaWHEREASE.colido not[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Palisade mesophyll cells andE.coliboth havecell membranes(✓\checkmark✓) andcytoplasm(✓\checkmark✓). They also both can havecell walls(✓\checkmark✓), however the cell wall inE.coliis composed ofpeptidoglycan, whereas the cell wall in palisade mesophyll cells is composed ofcellulose(✓\checkmark✓). Palisade mesophyll cells are full ofmembrane boundorganelles such as the golgi apparatus, which gives them acompartmentalisedstructure, whereasE.colido nothave a compartmentalised structure or membrane bound organelles (✓\checkmark✓). Both palisade mesophyll cells andE.colihaveribosomes(✓\checkmark✓), butE.colihave70Sribosomes and palisade mesophyll cells have80Sribosomes  (✓\checkmark✓). DNA is also stored differently in palisade mesophyll cells andE.coli. Palisade mesophyll cells store their DNA inside thenucleusand it has alinearstructure, whereasE.colihave DNA floating freely in the cytoplasm as anucleoid(✓\checkmark✓) and can sometimes contain extra DNA in the form of aplasmid(✓\checkmark✓). E.coli can also have external structures such aspilior flagella (✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]
