list.title: Question 71
list.content:
The diagram depicts a single-celled organism living in freshwater that faces water constantly moving into its cell due to osmosis.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e5d92e73-ab20-43da-aee4-b427dbf75796/images/c2bb4cec-e54b-4a2c-8f44-13ddf6b20f8d/BI2792.png)

[Source: Adapted fromFile: Paramecium caudatum.svg.(2024, March 12). Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved 04:34, April 23, 2025 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File.svg&oldid=859786930.CC Public Domain]To prevent bursting, the cell actively pumps out excess water using specialised structures. This process is an example of:A.\hspace{1em}Obtaining nutrientsB.\hspace{1em}Eliminating waste productsC.\hspace{1em}Responding to external stimuliD.\hspace{1em}Maintaining homeostasis
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Homeostasis is the maintenance of a stable internal environment. The organism pumping out of excess water is a mechanism to keep its osmolarity stable and different from the outside of the cell. Therefore,Choice Dis correct.The organism is not taking in or making any substance for energy and growth, soChoice Ais incorrect.Excess water may be considered a waste product. However, the primary purpose of the pump is to regulate osmolarity and prevent lysis. Waste products typically refer to metabolic wastes like carbon dioxide or nitrogenous compounds. Therefore,Choice Bis incorrect.The active pumping out of water is the organism's way of maintaining internal conditions rather than just a direct response to the stimulus, and soChoice Cis incorrect.

list.title: Question 72
list.content: Outline the role of auxin in positive phototropism.[3]Explain the evidence that supports the theory that eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells.[5]Explain how the products of the light-dependent stage of photosynthesis are used in the light-independent stage to convert carbon dioxide into organic substances.[7]
list.markScheme:
Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​light is detected by group of proteinsORphototropins which trigger the movement of auxins by active transport[1]→\ce{ -> }​auxin efflux pumps move auxin so the concentration of auxins is more on the shadier side
and lesser on the side with more light[1]→\ce{ -> }​plant cells have auxin receptors[1]→\ce{ -> }​when auxin binds to these receptors ,transcription of genes for enzymeORexpansin[1]→\ce{ -> }​auxin causes movement of  hydrogen ions from cytoplasm into the cell walls[1]→\ce{ -> }​hydrogen ions and expansionORenzyme loosens cellulose fibresORfibres of cell wall[1]→\ce{ -> }​causes cells on the shaded side of shoot tip to elongate[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Light is detectedbyphototropinsand this triggers the movement of auxins byactive transport(✓\checkmark✓). Auxinefflux pumpsmove auxins fromcytoplasmintocell walls, so that theconcentrationof auxin ismoreon theshadier side(✓\checkmark✓) and less on the side with more light. When auxin binds toreceptorson the cells,genesfor the enzymeexpansinareexpressed(✓\checkmark✓).Expansin, and thepumping of protonsfrom the cytoplasm into the cell wall cause thelooseningofcellulose fibres(✓\checkmark✓) in the cell walls, leading toelongationof thecells(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfiveof the following:→\ce{ -> }​theory of endosymbiosis proposes that mitochondriaORchloroplasts have evolved from free-living prokaryotes that were engulfedORtaken in by endocytosis, by larger cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts have naked DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts divide by binary fission[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts divide independently of cell cycleORcell[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts about same size as prokaryotes[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts have 70S ribosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts can synthesise their own proteins[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts have double membranes[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts have inner membrane likeORsimilar in structure to prokaryotesANDouter membrane likeORsimilar in structure to eukaryotes[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA of mitochondriaORchloroplasts is more closely relatedORmore similar to prokaryotic DNA than to nuclear DNA of eukaryotic cells,ORrRNAORribosomal RNA more closely relatedORmore similar to prokaryotes than eukaryotes[1]→\ce{ -> }​observations of modern examples of endosymbiosis OR given examples of present day endosymbiosis, provide support for the theory[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The endosymbiotictheorysupports the evidence thatmitochondriaandchloroplastsin eukaryotic cellsevolved from prokaryoticcells, which were taken in by larger cells throughendocytosis(✓\checkmark✓). The evidence supporting this theory includes the fact that these organelles havenaked DNA(✓\checkmark✓), divide bybinary fission(✓\checkmark✓), cansynthesisetheirown proteins(✓\checkmark✓) and havedouble membranesaround the outside (✓\checkmark✓).Anysevenof the following: (drawing showing the Calvin cycle with the steps described below):→\ce{ -> }​products of the light-dependent reaction are essential for the light-independent reactions[1]→\ce{ -> }​light-dependent reactions produce ATP, NADPH and oxygen[1]→\ce{ -> }​ATP and NADPH are used in the light-independent reactionsORCalvin cycle[1]→\ce{ -> }​light-independent reactions convert carbon dioxide into glucose and other organic molecules[1]→\ce{ -> }​enzyme RuBisCO fixes carbon dioxide[1]→\ce{ -> }​causes 1 x RuBP to bind to 1 x carbon dioxide[1]→\ce{ -> }​6 C compound is unstable and forms two 3C compounds of glycerate-3-phosphateORGP[1]→\ce{ -> }​ATP and NADPH are used to convert glycerate-3-phosphateORGP to triose phosphateORTP[1]→\ce{ -> }​some of the triose phosphateORTP leaves the cycle to form carbohydrates, most is used to reform RuBP[1]→\ce{ -> }​regeneration of RuBP requires energy in the form of ATP[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Light-dependentreactions of photosynthesis produceATP, NADPH(✓\checkmark✓) and oxygen. Oxygen is a by-product, ATP and NADPH are used in the light-independent reactions. In the stroma of the chloroplast,carbon dioxidecombines withRuBP(✓\checkmark✓), a 5C compound catalysed by the enzymeRubisco(✓\checkmark✓). The6C compoundformed isunstableand splits intotwo molecules of glycerate-3-phosphate(✓\checkmark✓).ATP and NADPH(✓\checkmark✓) are used to convertglycerate-3-phosphate into triose phosphate(✓\checkmark✓). Some of themoleculesoftriose phosphate leavethecycleto formglucose(✓\checkmark✓) or other carbohydrates,mostof it isusedtoregeneratethe5C RuBP(✓\checkmark✓).RegenerationofRuBPagain requiresATP(✓\checkmark✓) obtained from the light-dependent reactions.For additional detail‾\underline{\textrm{For additional detail}}For additional detail​:  see 5:26 in Photosynthesis Key Concept Video:https://www.revisionvillage.com/ib-biology/hl/key-concepts/?keyConceptId=cd710a11-a37d-4f93-aed3-30e4e1d75e55A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 73
list.content: Distinguish between the structure and location of chromosomes found in eukaryotes and prokaryotes.[5]Describe the stages of meiosis and how genetically unique, haploid gametes are created during the process.[7]Explain the information that can be deduced from a human karyogram.[3]
list.markScheme: Anyfiveof the following:→\ce{ -> }​eukaryotic chromosomes are found in the nucleusWHEREASprokaryotic chromosomes are found in the nucleoid regionORchromosomes of eukaryotes are contained within a membraneWHEREASprokaryotic chromosomes are not membrane bound[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotes have a circular chromosomeWHEREASeukaryotes have linear chromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotes typically have one chromosomeWHEREASeukaryotes typically have multiple chromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​in eukaryotic chromosomes, DNA is associated with histone proteinsWHEREASprokaryotic chromosomes do not contain histones[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic chromosomes do not contain centromeresWHEREASeukaryotic chromosomes do[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic chromosomes do not contain telomeresWHEREASeukaryotic chromosomes do[1]→\ce{ -> }​eukaryotic chromosomes carry more genetic informationORDNAORgenesTHANprokaryotic chromosomes[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Eukaryotic chromosomes are found in thenucleuswhereas prokaryotic chromosomes are found in thenucleoidregion (✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotes typically containone, circularchromosome (✓\checkmark✓)  whereas eukaryotes  havemultiple, linearchromosomes (✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotic chromosomesdo notcontaincentromeresandtelomeres(✓\checkmark✓), whereas eukaryotic chromosomes do (✓\checkmark✓).Anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​all the DNA in a cell is replicated during interphase[1]→\ce{ -> }​so cells are diploidORcontain homologous chromosomes when they enter meiosis[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous chromosomes pairANDbecome visibleORcondense  in prophase I[1]→\ce{ -> }​crossing over occurs between the non-sister chromatids of homologous chromosomes during prophase I[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous chromosomes are moved to the equator of the cell by spindle microtubulesANDrandomly orientated OR independently assorted in metaphase I[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous chromosomes are pulled to opposite sides of the cell by spindle microtubules in anaphase I[1]→\ce{ -> }​one diploid cell is split into two haploid cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​chromatids condenseORbecome visible during prophase II[1]→\ce{ -> }​pairs of sister chromatids are moved to the equator of the cell by spindle microtubules during metaphase IIANDrandomly orientatedORindependently assorted[1]→\ce{ -> }​pairs of sister chromatids are separated by spindle fibres in anaphase II[1]→\ce{ -> }​nuclear membrane reforms in telophase IIANDfour haploid cells are formed from the two haploid cells of 	meiosis[1]→\ce{ -> }​crossing over during prophase IANDindependent assortmentORrandom alignment of homologous chromosomes in metaphase IORmetaphase II result in unique gametes[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:All of the DNA in a cell isreplicatedduringinterphase(✓\checkmark✓), so cells arediploidwhen they enter meiosis (✓\checkmark✓).Homologouschromosomespair up, becomevisible(✓\checkmark✓) andcrossing overof non-sister chromatids occur duringprophase I(✓\checkmark✓). Then, homologous chromosomes are moved to theequatorof the cell byspindle microtubulesandrandomly orientatedduringmetaphase I(✓\checkmark✓). Homologous chromosomes are pulled to theopposite polesof the cell by spindle fibres inanaphase I(✓\checkmark✓) and onediploid cellis split intotwo haploidcells during telophase I (✓\checkmark✓). The cells then enter meiosis II. Thepairsofsister chromatidsareindependently assortedto form a single line along the equator of the cell, inmetaphase II(✓\checkmark✓). Duringanaphase IIthe centromeres split and thesister chromatidsare pulled toopposite polesof the cell (✓\checkmark✓). Intelophase IIthenuclear membrane reformsaround the chromosomes, and after cytokinesis,4 new haploid, non-identical,  daughter cells are formed from the2 haploid cellsthat resulted frommeiosis I(✓\checkmark✓).Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​a karyogram is an image showing the positions of centromeres and banding patterns of stainedORdyed homologous chromosomes ordered by decreasing length[1]→\ce{ -> }​biological sex determined by XX and XYORsex chromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​whether non-disjunction has occurred is determined by the presence or absence of chromosome (s)[1]→\ce{ -> }​presence of chromosomal abnormalities (such as breakages or translocation) determined by the banding patternORsize of chromosome[1]→\ce{ -> }​indication of chromosome disorders such as Down syndrome, which is caused by trisomy 21[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:A karyogram is an image showing the positions ofcentromeresandbanding patternsof stainedhomologous chromosomesordered by decreasing length (✓\checkmark✓). A karyogram can be used to deducebiological sex(✓\checkmark✓) or the presence ofchromosomal abnormalities(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

Retrieved June 19, 2022, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synechococcus_elongatus Copyright under CC BY 3.0]Compare and contrast the structure of a mictochondrion with the structure of the cell shown in the diagram.[2]Explain why the cell in the diagram is structurally similar to a mitochondrion.[2]
list.markScheme: Anytwoof the following:Similarities→\ce{ -> }​bothhave plasma membranes[1]→\ce{ -> }​bothcontain circularORnaked DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondrial ribosomes are more similar in sizeORstructure to prokaryotes than eukaryotesOR bothcontain 70S ribosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​bothare similar in size[1]→\ce{ -> }​bothare similar shapesORovalORelongated[1]→\ce{ -> }​bothhave ATPase proteins embedded in surrounding membrane[1]Differences→\ce{ -> }​mitochondria do not have a cell wallORa capsule whereas, prokaryotes do[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotes may have flagellaORpili but mitochondria do not[1]Answer must include at least one difference and one similarity to gain full marks[2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The cell in the diagram is a prokaryotic cell and is similar in structure to a mitochondrion, as mitochondrialribosomesare moresimilar in sizeandstructureto prokaryotes than eukaryotes, (✓\checkmark✓), and they both havenaked circular DNA(✓\checkmark✓). However mitochondriado not have a cell wall(✓\checkmark✓), whereasprokaryotic cells do.Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​endosymbiotic theory[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondria evolved from free-living prokaryotes[1]→\ce{ -> }​that were engulfedBUTnot digested by larger prokaryotes[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The prokaryotic cell in the diagram has structural similarities to a mitochondrion, due to theendosymbiotic theory(✓\checkmark✓) which explains that mitochondria evolved fromfree-living prokaryotes(✓\checkmark✓) that wereengulfed though not digested(✓\checkmark✓) by larger cells.

[Source: Adapted from Itayba, Hebrew Wikipedia (2006, March 1).FileMicroscope Siemens, 1960.jpg - wikimedia commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved March 4, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_microscope_Siemens,_1960.jpg Copyright under CC BY 3.0]A.\hspace{1em}1000 xB.\hspace{1em}100 xC.\hspace{1em}0.1 xD.\hspace{1em}10000 x
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Magnification is calculated using the equation image size divided by actual size. Both numbers must be the same units. The image size of the magnification bar is 5 mm, or 5000 µm, the actual size of the magnification bar is 5 µm. 5000 µm ÷ 5 µm = 1000 x.Choice Ais correct.Choices B, CandDare incorrect.

list.title: Question 77
list.content: Electron microscopy provides images of cells with significantly higher resolution when compared to light microscopy. Evaluate the implications and limitations of relying primarily on electron micrographs to understand cell function.[3]Explain how advances in microscopy have contributed to our understanding of cell structure and function.[4]Discuss the evidence for and against the idea that prokaryotic cells are “simple” compared to eukaryotic cells.[8]
list.markScheme: anythreeof the following,must include at leastoneimplication andonelimitationImplications→\ce{ -> }​fine detail resolution has led to a more detailed understanding of structure-function relationships[1]→\ce{ -> }​discovery of new organelles and structures[1]Limitations→\ce{ -> }​requires complex sample preparation[1]→\ce{ -> }​sample preparation can leave artefacts[1]→\ce{ -> }​samples must be fixed, dead, meaning no dynamic cellular processes can be observed[1]→\ce{ -> }​pigmentation or colour is not detected[1]→\ce{ -> }​maximum understanding comes from combining information from both light and electron microscopy[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Electron microscopy gives us verydetailed images, which let us see how the tiny parts of a cell arestructured to fulfiltheirfunctions(✓\checkmark✓). It has also led to the discovery ofnew things insidecells (✓\checkmark✓). Unfortunately, toprepare specimensfor electron microscopy, they must be treated in such a way that they arekilled, and so wecannot observe processeshappening in real time (✓\checkmark✓).anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​light microscopy allowed for the initial visualisation of cells and basic structures[1]→\ce{ -> }​staining techniques have enhanced the visibility of cell components[1]→\ce{ -> }​fluorescence microscopy enables visualisation and localisation of specific molecules[1]→\ce{ -> }​live-imaging techniques allow dynamic processes to be observed[1]→\ce{ -> }​electron microscopy provides significantly higher resolution than light microscopy[1]→\ce{ -> }​transmission electron microscopy reveals details of the internal structure of organelles[1]→\ce{ -> }​scanning electron microscopy provides 3-D images of cell surfacesORcell shape[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Light microscopy first allowed us to seecellsand theirbasicparts (✓\checkmark✓). Later,stainingmade it easier to see these parts moreclearly(✓\checkmark✓).Fluorescencemicroscopy has allowed scientists to visualise and pinpoint thelocationsof specific molecules within cells (✓\checkmark✓).Electronmicroscopy providesfar greater resolutionthan light microscopy (✓\checkmark✓), making it possible to seeinternal structureslike mitochondria and membranes infine detail(✓\checkmark✓).anyeightof the following:In favour→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells lack membrane-bound organellesORhave less compartmentalisation[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells have a single, circular chromosome; eukaryotic cells have multiple linear chromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells are generally smaller[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells reproduce by binary fission, which is less complex than mitosis/meiosis[1]Against→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells efficiently carry out all life processes within a single cell, demonstrating functional sophistication[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells exhibit diverse and complex metabolic pathways[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells exhibit unique metabolic pathways, ie chemosynthesis[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells can engage in cell signaling[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells have highly specialised adaptations (ie flagellae)[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells have a high surface area to volume ratio, increasing the exchange rate with the surroundings[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells are structurally simpler but functionally complex[1]→\ce{ -> }​evaluation of the application of the word “simple”[1][8 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Prokaryotes are generallysmaller(✓\checkmark✓) than most eukaryotic cells, and they reproduce bybinary fission(✓\checkmark✓) instead of mitosis or meiosis. Prokaryotic cells are often called more simple than eukaryotic cells, but it is important todistinguish between structure and function(✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotic cells may appear simple, but they still carry out all of thefunctions of life(✓\checkmark✓) and have some that are unique to prokaryotes. Although prokaryotesdo not have membrane-bound organelles(✓\checkmark✓), they still havecomplex metabolicpathways like cellular respiration and even pathways eukaryotes do not have, likechemosynthesis(✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotes can communicate with each other viacell signallingpathways like quorum sensing (✓\checkmark✓) and also have highlyspecialised structuressuch as flagellae for motility (✓\checkmark✓). The term “simple” is an oversimplification of a superficial observation.A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 78
list.content: Which characteristic isnottrue for both mitochondria and chloroplasts?A.\hspace{1em}They are present in both eukaryotes and prokaryotes.B.\hspace{1em}They are both able to self replicate.C.\hspace{1em}They are both able to synthesise proteins.D.\hspace{1em}They both contain circular DNA.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Chloroplasts and mitochondria are present only in eukaryotes. ThereforeChoice Ais the correct answer.Mitochondria and chloroplasts are both able to self replicate (Choice B), synthesise proteins (Choice C) and contain circular DNA (Choice D).

list.title: Question 79
list.content: A researcher labelled two different proteins with molecules that emit light of distinct colours when illuminated with a specific wavelength of light. To determine if these proteins are present in the same location in the cell, which type of microscopy would be most appropriate?A.\hspace{1em}Bright field microscopyB.\hspace{1em}Scanning electron microscopyC.\hspace{1em}Fluorescence microscopyD.\hspace{1em}Transmission electron microscopy
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Fluorescence microscopy uses specific wavelengths of light to excite fluorescent molecules, the labels, causing them to emit light at different wavelengths. Using appropriate filters, the light emitted from each can be detected to determine their locations. Therefore,Choice Cis correct.Bright field microscopy is the term used to describe a common light microscopy technique where specimens appear dark against a bright background due to the direct transmission of light through the sample. Bright field microscopy would not be able to excite specific fluorescent molecules or distinguish between particular wavelengths of light, soChoice Ais incorrect.Scanning electron microscopy uses a stream of electrons to produce an image of the surface of an organism and does not use or detect any wavelength of light, soChoice Bis incorrect.Transmission electron microscopy passes a stream of electrons through a thin specimen to visualise internal structures and does not use or detect any wavelength of light, soChoice Dis incorrect.

The electron micrograph shows a prokaryotic cell,Cyclotella litoralis. What is the actual diameter of the cell in this image?

When the scale bar, which represents 10 µm, is measured, it is shown to be 1 cm long in the image. 3.5 multiplied by 10 is 35 µm.Choice Dis correct.Choices A, BandCare incorrect.

The electron micrograph shows a sarcomere, the smallest functional unit of striated muscle tissue. What is the actual length between the two Z lines?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c4757206-7907-4040-94a2-08079ed88b94/images/b762a3a8-46a3-4d64-a154-328e5b7831c2/BI0562i.png)

[Source: Adapted from Loison, O., Weitkunat , M., Kaya-Çopur , A., Nascimento Alves, C., Matzat , T., & Spletter , M. L. (2018).Category: sarcomeres. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved March 5, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/CategoryCopyright under CC BY 3.0][Ruler tool, cm]A.\hspace{1em}10 µmB.\hspace{1em}1 mmC.\hspace{1em}1 cmD.\hspace{1em}1 µm
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The length between the two Z lines is 4.5 cm, which is equivalent to 45000 µm. Actual length is calculated using the equation; image size divided by magnification. 45000 µm ÷ 45000 x = 1 µm.Choice Dis correct.Choices A, BandCare incorrect.

list.title: Question 83
list.content: A student, learning to use a microscope, observed a pollen grain under a microscope with a magnification of ×100. Using an eyepiece graticule, they measured the diameter of the pollen grain to be 25 divisions. At this magnification, 1 division on the eyepiece graticule equals 3μ\muμm. To allow the student to measure more pollen grains and to calculate a mean diameter, which of the following conclusions on the experimental work so far is/are correct?I.\hspace{1em}Increasing the magnification of the objective lens would widen the field of view.II.\hspace{.7em}The actual diameter of the pollen grain is 75μ\muμm.III.\hspace{.5em}If the magnification were increased to ×200, each eyepiece graticule division would represent a smaller actual size.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis not true. Increasing the magnification will narrow the field of view. This is a common student mistake. As magnification increases, the observer is focusing on a smaller area, like zooming in with a camera.Statement IIis true. The actual diameter of the pollen grain is calculated as 25 divisions × 3 µm/division = 75 µm.Statement IIIis true. If the magnification were increased by switching to a higher power objective, the same number of eyepiece graticule divisions would span a smaller actual distance on the specimen.Choice Cis correct because it contains the proper combination ofStatement IIandStatement III.Choice A, Choice BandChoice Ddo not contain the proper combination of statements.

list.title: Question 84
list.content: Which organelle is formed by a vesicle derived from the cell membrane?A.\hspace{1em}Food vacuoleB.\hspace{1em}RibosomeC.\hspace{1em}Golgi apparatusD.\hspace{1em}Smooth endoplasmic reticulum
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:When a cell takes in material through endocytosis, it produces a vesicle derived from the cell membrane, which is how a food vacuole is formed.Ribosomes are involved in translation (Choice B), the golgi apparatus sorts, packages and modifies proteins (Choice C) and the smooth endoplasmic reticulum, among other functions, synthesizes lipids (Choice D).

list.title: Question 85
list.content: Which organism contains DNA in just two different types of organelle?A.\hspace{1em}A treeB.\hspace{1em}A mushroomC.\hspace{1em}An ArchaeonD.\hspace{1em}A seaweed
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:All eukaryotic organisms contain organismal DNA in the cell nucleus and mitochondrial DNA in the mitochondria. Photosynthetic organisms additionally contain DNA in the chloroplasts. So, an organism that is a eukaryote but not photosynthetic contains DNA in exactly two organelles. A mushroom is a non-photosynthetic eukaryote, so a mushroom contains DNA in exactly two organelles.A tree (Choice A) and a seaweed (Choice D) each contain DNA in three organelles (nucleus, mitochondria, and chloroplasts). An Archaeon (Choice C) lacks membrane-bound organelles; its DNA is contained within the cytoplasm.
